title: First Zomato Now Swiggy: Customer In Hyderabad Refuses Food From Muslim Delivery Man
text:
First Zomato Now Swiggy: Customer In Hyderabad Refuses Food From Muslim Delivery Man

First Zomato Now Swiggy: Customer In Hyderabad Refuses Food From Muslim Delivery Man

'Food has no religion': Zomato's crisp reply to a customer who refused to accept a order assigned to a Muslim delivery boy, made waves across the country.

However, this nauseating religious stigma persists and this time a Swiggy customer has been at it.

According to a TOI report, customer in Hyderabad’s old city area who had ordered a dish on food delivery platform Swiggy, refused to accept it when it came through a Muslim boy.

PTI/Picture For Representation

Soon after the blatant religious discrimination, the Muslim delivery boy, rushed to the police station to lodge a complaint against the bigoted customer.

The report states that the customer named Ajay Kumar from Aliabad, ordered a snack item, Chicken-65, from Grand Bawarchi restaurant at Falaknuma, through Swiggy.

Don't Miss 2.5 K SHARES 1.4 K SHARES 1.5 K SHARES 30.2 K SHARES

The blaring irony hear is that the Grand Bawarchi restaurant is a Muslim chain!

In the order, Ajay Kumar clearly stated.'Very less spicy. And, please select Hindu delivery person. All ratings will be based on this.'

Heights of stupidity! Hindu man from #Hyderabad orders Chicken 65 from Grand Bawarchi, owned by a Muslim, but abuses Muslim delivery boy of @swiggy_in for the order being less spicy. @amjedmbt asks Swiggy to register case against Ajay Kumar. pic.twitter.com/suB0djnsLw — krishnamurthy (@krishna0302) October 23, 2019

But when Ajay received a call from a delivery boy named Suleman, he lost the plot. He went on to hurl abuses against the delivery boy when he received a call enquiring about his exact location of delivery.

After the controversy Amzadullah Khan president of a political party Majlis Bachao Tehreek (MBT), expressed shock saying,“How can the food be rejected based on religion?

An HT report states that Ajay, while speaking to the Swiggy customer care said that he doesn't mind losing the Rs 95 as cancellation fee but he would never accept an order from a Muslim man.

Swiggy has not yet reacted to this incident.

In a similar incident in July, a man named Amit Shukla in Jabalpur in Madhya Pradesh cancelled his order as “they allocated a non Hindu rider” for his delivery.

Deepinder Goyal, the founder of the food delivery platform added "We are proud of the idea of India - and the diversity of our esteemed customers and partners. We aren’t sorry to lose any business that comes in the way of our values."

Bringing food into the religious dynamics is utterly ridiculous, unfortunately there are some people who will just never learn!
